history.content:
Applied Math major here w. CS concentration (188, 189, 170) and a Stats minor here. I had this question as well a while back before I declared, and what I did to make my choice:

Remember, what YOU think employers would think is pure speculation. Employers are still people, so how they "view" degrees (if it even matters) is purely subjective. A Math degree from Berkeley will be impressive regardless of "pure" or "applied," so the important thing is you graduate with those degrees. So, you should ask yourself, what kind of classes do you want to take and what do you want to learn?

I chose to do App. Math w. CS conc. and a Stats minor because I genuinely enjoy those topics. I wanted to explore higher levels of Math post-54 (Fall 2014 admit so 54 was a requirement; really opened my eyes to Math since it's a very different branch of Math vs. Calculus), LOVED probability/statistics, and was interested in AI/ML so I took the path that let me do these things. I didn't do it to impress employers (and let's face it, it's undergrad), but to learn the necessary skills I enjoy that'll help me with what I want to do with my life (not specific career, but fields). 

If you're interested and feel passionate about Math for the sake of Math, then go for a pure math degree. If you want to explore fields outside of Math and CS that intersect with what you learn in your Math/CS classes, then go for an Applied Math degree.

history.content:
Hello, 

I am a junior majoring in cs and doubling in either pure or applied math, and I was just wondering which would look better to potential employers. I've heard some say an actual math degree is more impressive which is useful because of the math background people believe to be required for machine learning and deep learning etc. I've also heard applied math may look better since you can list your applied math cluster , which in my case is "machine learning" ( cs 170 cs 189 and stat 134). Perhaps employers might think you're more practical if they see applied math on your resume, but pure could allow for better chances for grad school? I apologize in advance if the content of this post is not too related to cs, but I think it's an applicable question for aspiring data scientists. 

Oh also, the extra class I would have to take for pure math would be analysis ii/topology, which I have high interest in since I enjoyed analysis i. However, it might not be the useful (only measure theory is for probability I think). Thanks in advance!
history.subject: Pure or Applied Math for Data Science
